summary: James N. Roethe was a Commission staff member involved in taking depositions related to potential CIA involvement in assassination plots and other sensitive matters. He is documented as participating in the deposition of Frank Sturgis and Wilfredo Navarro on April 4, 1975, and in the deposition of Frank Sturgis on April 3, 1975. Additionally, he authored a memorandum summarizing information obtained from George Brewer regarding the CIA's Washington Field Office activities. His role appears to be primarily focused on gathering information and testimony related to CIA activities and potential wrongdoing.
significance: James N. Roethe's significance in the JFK context lies in his role as a Commission staff member actively involved in investigating potential CIA involvement in assassination plots and other sensitive activities. His work contributes to the broader understanding of the CIA's operations and connections to individuals like Frank Sturgis, who were implicated in various controversial events.
